a.g: Those who disbelieve and avert [people] from the way of Allah - He will waste their deeds.

And those who believe and do righteous deeds and believe in what has been sent down upon Muhammad - and it is the truth from their Lord - He will remove from them their misdeeds and amend their condition.
That is because those who disbelieve follow falsehood, and those who believe follow the truth from their Lord. Thus does Allah present to the people their comparisons.

So when you meet those who disbelieve [in battle], strike [their] necks until, when you have inflicted slaughter upon them, then secure their bonds, and either [confer] favor afterwards or ransom [them] until the war lays down its burdens. That [is the command]. And if Allah had willed, He could have taken vengeance upon them [Himself], but [He ordered armed struggle] to test some of you by means of others. And those who are killed in the cause of Allah - never will He waste their deeds.
He will guide them and amend their condition
And admit them to Paradise, which He has made known to them.
O you who have believed, if you support Allah, He will support you and plant firmly your feet.
But those who disbelieve - for them is misery, and He will waste their deeds.
That is because they disliked what Allah revealed, so He rendered worthless their deeds.
Have they not traveled through the land and seen how was the end of those before them? Allah destroyed [everything] over them, and for the disbelievers is something comparable.
That is because Allah is the protector of those who have believed and because the disbelievers have no protector.

Indeed, Allah will admit those who have believed and done righteous deeds to gardens beneath which rivers flow, but those who disbelieve enjoy themselves and eat as grazing livestock eat, and the Fire will be a residence for them.
And how many a city was stronger than your city [Makkah] which drove you out? We destroyed them; and there was no helper for them.
So is he who is on clear evidence from his Lord like him to whom the evil of his work has been made attractive and they follow their [own] desires?

Is the description of Paradise, which the righteous are promised, wherein are rivers of water unaltered, rivers of milk the taste of which never changes, rivers of wine delicious to those who drink, and rivers of purified honey, in which they will have from all [kinds of] fruits and forgiveness from their Lord, like [that of] those who abide eternally in the Fire and are given to drink scalding water that will sever their intestines?

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Etiquette of Quran Recitation
Indeed, God has not granted permission for anything as He has granted permission for a beautiful voice [husn al-sawt] reciting the Qur'an. A hadith: "God has not granted permission for anything as He has granted permission for a beautiful voice reciting the Qur'an," agreed upon from the narration of Abu Hurayrah with the wording: "God has not granted permission for anything as He has granted permission for a prophet who chants the Qur'an." Muslim added: "for a prophet with a beautiful voice." And in another narration of his: "like His permission for a prophet who chants the Qur'an." And he, peace be upon him, said: "He is not of us who does not chant [yataghanna] the Qur'an." It was said he meant self-sufficiency [al-istighna'], and it was said he meant melodious recitation and repeating melodies with it, and this is closer according to the people of language. And it was narrated: "That the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, was one night waiting for 'A'ishah, may God be pleased with her, and she was delayed upon him. So he, peace be upon him, said: 'What detained you?' She said: 'O Messenger of God, I was listening to the recitation of a man; I have not heard a better voice than his.' So he, peace be upon him, stood until he listened to him for a long time, then returned and said, peace be upon him: 'This is Salim, the freed slave of Abu Hudhayfah. Praise be to God who has placed in my nation one like him.'" And he, peace be upon him, also listened one night to 'Abd Allah ibn Mas'ud, and with him were Abu Bakr and 'Umar, may God be pleased with them both, and they stood for a long time, then he, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever wishes to recite the Qur'an fresh and tender as it was revealed, then let him recite it according to the recitation of Ibn Umm 'Abd." And he, peace be upon him, said to Ibn Mas'ud: "Recite to me." He said: "O Messenger of God, shall I recite to you when it was revealed to you?" He, peace be upon him, said: "Indeed, I love to hear it from another." So he recited, and the eyes of the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, overflowed [tafiyadan]. And he, peace be upon him, listened to the recitation of Abu Musa and said: "Indeed, this one has been given something from the Psalms [mazamir] of the family of David." That reached Abu Musa, so he said: "O Messenger of God, had I known you were listening, I would have beautified it for you with beautification." And Haytham the reciter saw the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, in a dream. He said: So he said to me: "Are you Haytham who adorns the Qur'an with your voice?" I said: "Yes." He said: "May God reward you well." And in the report: "The Companions of the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, when they gathered, would command one of them to recite a surah from the Qur'an." And indeed, 'Umar, may God be pleased with him, used to say to Abu Musa, may God be pleased with them both: "Remind us of our Lord," and he would recite near him until the time for prayer was almost half over, and it would be said: "O Commander of the Faithful, the prayer, the prayer!" So he would say: "Are we not in prayer?" indicating the saying of the Almighty: "And the remembrance of God is greater." And he, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever listens to a verse from the Book of God Almighty, it will be a light [nur] for him on the Day of Resurrection." And in the report: "Ten good deeds are written for him." And however great the reward for listening is, and the reciter is the cause of it, he is a partner in the reward, unless his intention is showing off and affectation. **(The Third Chapter: On the Inner Acts [a'mal al-batin] in Recitation)** And they are ten: Understanding the origin of the speech, then magnification, then presence of the heart [hudur al-qalb], then reflection [al-tadabbur], then comprehension, then removal of the obstacles to understanding, then specification, then being affected, then ascension, then disavowal. **The First:** Understanding the majesty of the speech and its loftiness, and the grace of God, glorified and exalted be He, and His gentleness with His creation in its descent from the throne of His majesty to the level of making His creation understand. So let him look at how gentle He is with His creation in conveying the meanings of His speech, which is an eternal attribute subsisting in His essence, to the understandings of His creation, and how that attribute became manifest to them within the folds of letters and sounds which are attributes of humans, since humans are incapable of reaching an understanding of the attributes of God Almighty except by means of the attributes of their own selves. And were it not for the concealment of the essence of the majesty of His speech with the garment of letters, no throne nor earth would have remained firm upon hearing the speech, and what is between them of the majesty of His dominion and the radiances of His light would have vanished. And were it not for God Almighty strengthening Moses, peace be upon him, he would not have been able to bear hearing His speech, just as the mountain could not bear the beginnings of His manifestation, where it crumbled to dust. And it is not possible to convey the majesty of the speech except with examples within the limit of the creation's understanding. For this reason, some of the knowers [al-'arifin] expressed it, saying: "Indeed, every letter of the speech of God Almighty in the Preserved Tablet [al-lawh al-mahfuz] is greater than Mount Qaf, and if the angels, peace be upon them, gathered together to lift a single letter, they would not be able to bear it, until Israfil, peace be upon him, who is the angel of the Tablet, comes and lifts it, and he lifts it by the permission of God Almighty and His mercy, not by his own strength and ability, but God Almighty enabled him for that and employed him in it." And indeed, some of the wise have shone in expressing the aspect of gentleness in conveying the meanings of the speech, despite the loftiness of its degree, to human understanding, and its establishment despite the deficiency of its rank. And he struck for it an example that did not fall short, which is that he called one of the kings a sage to the law of the prophets, peace be upon them. So the king asked him about matters, and he answered with what his understanding could not bear. So the king said: "What do you think of what..."

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Secrets of Zakat
Indeed, the Qur'an has alluded to it when the Most High said: **"If He were to ask you for it and press you, you would withhold."** Rather, the truth [al-haqq] in which there is no murkiness, and the justice [al-'adl] in which there is no oppression, is that no one from among the servants of God should take from the wealth of God except in the measure of a traveler's provision [zad al-rakib]. For all the servants of God are riders upon the mounts of their bodies, journeying to the presence of the Sovereign Judge. So whoever takes more than that, then withholds it from another needy rider, he is an oppressor, an abandoner of justice, and one who has departed from the intended wisdom [al-hikmah]; he is an ingrate [kafir] for the favor [ni'mah] of God, the Most High, upon him through the Qur'an, the Messenger, the intellect [al-'aql], and all the other means by which he knew that whatever is beyond a traveler's provision is a burden upon him in this world [al-dunya] and the Hereafter [al-akhirah]. So whoever comprehends the wisdom of God, the Most High, in all categories of existent things, he becomes capable of fulfilling the duty of gratitude [shukr]. To exhaustively detail this would require volumes, and even then it would only capture a little. We have only mentioned this much so that the cause for the truthfulness in His, the Most High's, statement may be known: **"And few of My servants are grateful."** And so that the joy of Iblisâ€”may God curse himâ€”at his statement may be known: **"And you will not find most of them grateful."** Therefore, he who does not know the meaning of all this and other matters beyond itâ€”whose foundational principles lifetimes would be spent without exhaustingâ€”does not know the meaning of this verse. As for the explanation [tafsir] of the verse and the meaning of its wording, anyone who knows the language knows it. And by this, the difference between the meaning [al-ma'na] and the explanation [al-tafsir] becomes clear to you.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Poverty and Abstinence
Know that poverty [faqr] is an expression for the lack of what one is in need of. As for the lack of what one has no need for, it is not called poverty. And if what is needed is present and attainable, the one in need is not poor. When you understand this, you will not doubt that every existent besides God, the Exalted, is poor, because it is in need of the continuation of its existence in the next moment, and the continuation of existence is a gift [fadl] obtained from God, the Exalted, for its existence. If there were in existence a being whose existence is not obtained from another, He is the Absolutely Self-Sufficient [al-Ghani al-Mutlaq]. It is inconceivable for such a being to be except One. Thus, in existence there is only One Self-Sufficient, and everyone besides Him is in need of Him to supply the continuation of their existence. To this exclusivity, the indication is in His saying, the Exalted: "And God is the Self-Sufficient [al-Ghani], and you are the poor [al-fuqara']." This is the meaning of poverty in the absolute sense. However, our intent is not to explain absolute poverty, but poverty from wealth [al-mal] in particular. Otherwise, the poverty of the servant [al-'abd] in relation to the varieties of his needs is without limit, because his needs are without limit. Among that which is attained by wealthâ€”and it is this which we wish to explain now onlyâ€”we say: Everyone who lacks wealth, we call him poor in relation to the wealth he lacks, if that which is lacking is needed in his right.
